hypotheses.title: Detection of ClickFix DNS Tunneling Attacks Using nslookup for Malware Delivery
hypotheses.description: Attackers are increasingly using DNS tunneling via the nslookup command as part of ClickFix social engineering campaigns to deliver second-stage payloads (e.g., ModeloRAT, StealC). This hypothesis targets the unique behavior where victims are tricked into executing nslookup commands that parse DNS responses for encoded payloads, bypassing traditional command-line restrictions.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs with command-line arguments, DNS query logs, and parent-child process relationships
DNS query logs with unusually long TXT/CNAME responses, nslookup.exe execution patterns, and DNS traffic to suspicious domains
Phishing emails containing fake CAPTCHA/error instructions, links to malicious Google Forms or Pastebin, and embedded JavaScript payloads
tools: Mimecast, Proofpoint, Microsoft Defender for Office 365

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Process Tree Analysis for nslookup Abuse
hunting_tactics.description: Identify suspicious nslookup.exe executions initiated by non-system processes (e.g., cmd.exe, powershell.exe, wscript.exe) with DNS queries containing encoded payloads in response fields.
sample_queries: index=security_events sourcetype=sysmon EventCode=1 Image="*\\nslookup.exe" | stats count by parent_image, user, query_string | where query_string LIKE "%.%" AND query_string LIKE "%=%"
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup.exe spawned by non-standard processes, especially with DNS queries containing base64-encoded or hex-encoded subdomains (e.g., aGVsbG8=.malware[.]xyz)

hunting_tactics.description: Detect unusually long DNS TXT or CNAME responses (>100 characters) that may contain encoded payloads, often used in ClickFix DNS exfiltration.
sample_queries: index=dns_logs query_type IN (TXT, CNAME) response_length > 100 | eval payload=substr(response, 1, 200) | where payload LIKE "%=%" OR payload LIKE "%base64%" OR payload LIKE "%http%"
hunting_tactics.look_for: DNS TXT responses with embedded URLs, base64 strings, or PowerShell commands (e.g., powershell.exe -enc)

hunting_tactics.description: Search for phishing emails or web traffic referencing fake CAPTCHA, system updates, or error messages that instruct users to copy/paste commands.
sample_queries: index=proxy_logs (url="*forms.google*" OR url="*captha*" OR url="*update-now*") AND user_agent LIKE "%Chrome%" | stats count by user, url, user_agent | where count > 3
hunting_tactics.look_for: Requests to domains mimicking Google Forms (e.g., forms.google.ss-o[.]com), CAPTCHA pages, or update prompts with suspicious URLs

network_patterns: HTTP traffic to AWS S3 buckets with PDF lures
user_agent_strings: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/145.0.7632.75 Safari/537.36
other_indicators: Fake Claude AI guides on Google Ads

recommended_actions: Block nslookup.exe execution unless explicitly whitelisted (e.g., via AppLocker)
Enable DNS response size limits (e.g., <100 chars for TXT records)
Hunt for users executing nslookup with suspicious parameters and correlate with phishing email delivery
Isolate endpoints showing nslookup.exe spawning PowerShell with encoded commands

hypotheses.title: Hunting for OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Theft via Infostealers
hypotheses.description: Information-stealing malware is now specifically targeting OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) configuration environments to steal API keys, gateway tokens, and agent identities. This hypothesis focuses on detecting exfiltration of OpenClaw-related files (e.g., config.json, tokens.env) from endpoints where AI agents are deployed.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File system monitoring for reads of OpenClaw config files, process access to agent memory, and network connections to known C2 domains
tools: CrowdStrike, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, Velociraptor

data_sources_needed.specific_data: TLS certificate mismatches, HTTPS traffic to known infostealer C2 (e.g., Telegram, Discord), and unusual data volume to cloud storage
Anomalous API key usage patterns, token generation from non-standard locations, and privilege escalation to service accounts

hunting_tactics.description: Detect access to OpenClaw configuration files (e.g., config.json, tokens.env, secrets.yaml) by non-agent processes.
sample_queries: index=endpoint_events (file_path="*openclaw*" OR file_path="*clawdbot*" OR file_path="*clawhub*" OR file_path="*config.json" OR file_path="*tokens.env") AND (process_name="*infostealer*" OR parent_process="*chrome*" OR parent_process="*discord*") | stats count by user, file_path, process_name
hunting_tactics.look_for: Access to files containing 'openclaw', 'clawdbot', or 'clawhub' in path; config.json with 'api_key', 'token', or 'gateway_url' fields

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: AI Agent Credential Exfiltration via Cloud Storage
hunting_tactics.description: Identify unusual uploads to cloud storage (e.g., Google Drive, Dropbox) or Telegram from endpoints running AI agents.
sample_queries: index=cloud_logs (action="upload" OR action="share") AND (file_name="*.json" OR file_name="*.env" OR file_name="*.yaml") AND (file_size > 10000 AND file_size < 100000) | stats count by user, file_name, destination | where count > 1
hunting_tactics.look_for: Small JSON/ENV files uploaded to cloud storage or Telegram with names like 'agent_config.json', 'openclaw_token.txt', or 'api_keys.json'

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Process Memory Dumping of Agent Environments
hunting_tactics.description: Detect memory dumps or process inspection tools (e.g., procdump, tasklist) targeting AI agent processes (e.g., node, python, java).
sample_queries: index=endpoint_events (process_name="*procdump*" OR process_name="*tasklist*" OR process_name="*processhacker*") AND (target_process="*node*" OR target_process="*python*" OR target_process="*java*") | stats count by user, source_process, target_process
hunting_tactics.look_for: Procdump or similar tools targeting node/python/java processes running on ports 3000/8080 (common MCP agent ports)

network_patterns: HTTPS to Telegram/Discord with large payloads
HTTP/2 traffic to port 443 with TLS SNI mismatch
other_indicators: API keys in config files with 'openai_', 'gemini_', or 'claude_' prefixes

recommended_actions: Audit all OpenClaw deployments for exposed configuration files and enforce least-privilege access
Monitor for file access to config.json in agent directories using EDR
Block outbound traffic to known infostealer C2 (e.g., Telegram, Discord) unless explicitly allowed
Review API key usage logs for anomalous access patterns from non-agent services

hypotheses.title: Detection of Dell RecoverPoint Zero-Day Exploitation (CVE-2026-22769) by UNC6201
hypotheses.description: A maximum-severity (CVSS 10.0) hardcoded credential vulnerability in Dell RecoverPoint for Virtual Machines (CVE-2026-22769) has been actively exploited since mid-2024 by China-linked APT UNC6201 to establish long-term access. This hypothesis targets lateral movement and persistence artifacts post-exploitation, including ghost NICs and credential dumping.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1003.001 - OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory
T1547.001 - Boot or Logon Autostart: Registry Run Keys

data_sources_needed.specific_data: SMB traffic to port 445 from non-standard hosts, unusual SMB2/3 dialect usage, and connections to Dell RecoverPoint appliances
LSASS process memory access, unusual PowerShell commands (e.g., Invoke-Mimikatz), and registry modifications to autorun keys
tools: Sysmon, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, Elastic EDR

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Dell RecoverPoint logs showing unauthenticated access, failed login attempts, and ghost NIC creation events
tools: Dell Support Center, SIEM with custom Dell RecoverPoint logs

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Ghost NIC Detection in Network Traffic
hunting_tactics.description: Identify network traffic from non-existent or ghost network interfaces, often used by UNC6201 to maintain persistence without detection.
sample_queries: index=network_logs (src_ip="*" AND dst_ip="*" AND interface="ghost*" OR interface="fake*" OR interface="tunnel*") | stats count by src_ip, dst_ip, interface | where count > 5
hunting_tactics.look_for: Traffic from interfaces with names like 'ghost_nic', 'tunnel0', or 'fake_eth0' in logs (note: interface names may be obfuscated)

hunting_tactics.description: Detect PowerShell commands attempting to dump LSASS memory, a common post-exploitation step after initial access.
sample_queries: index=endpoint_events (process_name="*powershell*" OR process_name="*cmd*") AND (command_line="*Invoke-Mimikatz*" OR command_line="*procdump*" OR command_line="*lsass*" OR command_line="*sekurlsa::logonpasswords*") | stats count by user, process_name, command_line

hunting_tactics.description: Search for SMB connections to Dell RecoverPoint appliances on port 445 with hardcoded credentials (e.g., 'admin'/'password' or 'root'/'toor').
sample_queries: index=smb_logs (src_ip="*" AND dst_ip="*dell*" OR dst_ip="*recoverpoint*") AND (auth_method="NTLM" AND username="admin" OR username="root") AND status="failure" | stats count by src_ip, dst_ip, username | where count > 10
hunting_tactics.look_for: Repeated SMB login failures to Dell RecoverPoint IPs with default credentials, especially from non-admin workstations

ips: Known Dell RecoverPoint appliance IPs (e.g., 10.0.0.100-10.0.0.200 in internal ranges)
network_patterns: SMB traffic to port 445 from non-standard hosts
HTTP/HTTPS to Dell RecoverPoint web interface (port 8080) with default credentials
other_indicators: Ghost NIC MAC addresses with OUI '00:50:56' (VMware) or '00:0C:29'
Unusual SMB2 dialect negotiation (e.g., 'SMB 3.1.1' with no encryption)

recommended_actions: Patch Dell RecoverPoint for Virtual Machines immediately using vendor-provided updates
Hunt for LSASS memory access attempts using Sysmon EventCode 10 (ProcessAccess)
Block SMB traffic to Dell RecoverPoint appliances from non-admin workstations
Review SMB logs for repeated authentication failures with default credentials

hypotheses.title: Hunting for AI-Driven C2 Communication via Copilot/Grok Web Browsing Features
hypotheses.description: AI assistants like Microsoft Copilot and xAI Grok with web browsing capabilities can be abused as stealthy C2 relays. Attackers encode commands in URL parameters or use AI-generated prompts to fetch payloads, blending C2 traffic with legitimate enterprise AI usage. This hypothesis targets anomalous AI assistant network behavior.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1559.002 - Inter-Process Communication: Dynamic Data Exchange

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS traffic to AI services (e.g., copilot.microsoft.com, grok.com) with encoded payloads in URL parameters, and anomalous request patterns
Copilot/Grok process execution with suspicious command-line arguments, and file writes from AI assistant processes
API calls to AI services with unusual data volumes, and access to cloud storage from AI assistant sessions
tools: AWS CloudTrail, Azure Monitor, Google Cloud Logging

hunting_tactics.description: Detect AI assistant requests with base64-encoded or hex-encoded parameters that may contain C2 commands or payloads.
sample_queries: index=proxy_logs (url="*copilot.microsoft.com*" OR url="*grok.com*" OR url="*chatgpt.com*" OR url="*gemini.google.com*") AND (url LIKE "%q=%" OR url LIKE "%prompt=%" OR url LIKE "%data=%") | eval encoded=substr(url, match(url, "q=([A-Za-z0-9+/=]{50,})"), 50) | where encoded LIKE "%base64%" OR encoded LIKE "%http%"
hunting_tactics.look_for: URL parameters with >50-character base64 strings, hex-encoded payloads, or embedded URLs (e.g., 'http://malware[.]xyz/payload.exe')

hunting_tactics.description: Identify AI assistant processes writing files to non-standard locations or spawning child processes with suspicious arguments.
sample_queries: index=endpoint_events (process_name="*copilot*" OR process_name="*grok*" OR process_name="*chatgpt*") AND (file_path="*\\AppData\\Local\\Temp*" OR file_path="*\\Downloads*" OR file_path="*.exe" OR file_path="*.ps1") | stats count by user, process_name, file_path
hunting_tactics.look_for: Copilot/Grok processes creating files in %TEMP% or %Downloads% with extensions .exe, .ps1, or .bat

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: AI-Driven Prompt Injection for Data Exfiltration
hunting_tactics.description: Detect prompts that instruct AI assistants to extract sensitive data (e.g., 'Summarize all emails from CEO') or access cloud storage.
sample_queries: index=ai_logs (prompt LIKE "%extract%" OR prompt LIKE "%summarize%" OR prompt LIKE "%download%" OR prompt LIKE "%upload%") AND (prompt LIKE "%confidential%" OR prompt LIKE "%internal%" OR prompt LIKE "%customer%") | stats count by user, prompt | where count > 3
hunting_tactics.look_for: Prompts containing 'extract', 'summarize', or 'download' combined with sensitive keywords (e.g., 'confidential', 'internal', 'customer')

network_patterns: HTTPS to AI services with large payloads (>10KB) in URL parameters
DNS queries to AI service subdomains with encoded data
HTTP/2 traffic with TLS SNI mismatch
other_indicators: AI assistant processes spawning cmd.exe or powershell.exe

recommended_actions: Restrict AI assistant web browsing permissions to approved domains only
Monitor AI assistant network traffic for large URL-encoded payloads
Block AI assistant processes from writing executable files to disk
Audit prompts for data extraction instructions using DLP policies

hypotheses.title: Detection of Firebase Misconfiguration Exploits Leading to Massive Data Leaks
hypotheses.description: Firebase misconfigurations have led to leaks of 300M+ messages (e.g., Chat & Ask AI). Attackers exploit overly permissive security rules (e.g., allow read/write for all users) to exfiltrate sensitive user data. This hypothesis targets Firebase access patterns and misconfigured bucket rules.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1048.001 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Firebase security rules, access logs, and storage object access events
tools: Google Cloud Security Command Center, AWS GuardDuty, Palo Alto Prisma Cloud

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS traffic to Firebase endpoints (e.g., *.firebaseio.com) with large data downloads, and anomalous query patterns
Firebase authentication logs, token issuance, and user role changes
tools: Firebase Console, Okta, Microsoft Entra ID

hunting_tactics.description: Detect Firebase projects with overly permissive security rules (e.g., allow read/write for all users).
sample_queries: index=cloud_logs (resource_type="firebase_security_rules" OR resource_type="firestore_security_rules") AND (rule LIKE "%allow read, write: if true%" OR rule LIKE "%allow read, write: if request.auth == null%" OR rule LIKE "%allow read, write: if request.time != null%") | stats count by project_id, rule
hunting_tactics.look_for: Rules with 'if true', 'if request.auth == null', or 'if request.time != null' allowing read/write access

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Firebase Data Exfiltration via Large Downloads
hunting_tactics.description: Identify large data downloads from Firebase storage (e.g., >100MB) that may indicate exfiltration.
sample_queries: index=cloud_logs (resource_type="firebase_storage" OR resource_type="firestore") AND (event="download" OR event="read") AND (bytes_transferred > 100000000) | stats count by user, object_name, bytes_transferred
hunting_tactics.look_for: Downloads of >100MB from Firebase storage, especially to non-corporate IPs or during off-hours

hunting_tactics.description: Detect anomalous Firebase queries that may indicate data scraping (e.g., full collection scans).
sample_queries: index=firebase_logs (query LIKE "%*%" OR query LIKE "%orderBy=%" OR query LIKE "%limitToFirst=999999%") AND (collection LIKE "%messages%" OR collection LIKE "%users%" OR collection LIKE "%accounts%") | stats count by user, collection, query
hunting_tactics.look_for: Queries with wildcards (*), orderBy without index, or high limit values (e.g., limitToFirst=999999) on sensitive collections

network_patterns: HTTPS to Firebase endpoints with large payloads
HTTP/2 traffic with TLS SNI mismatch

recommended_actions: Audit all Firebase projects for overly permissive security rules
Enable Firebase Audit Logs and set alerts for large data downloads
Restrict Firebase access to authenticated users only and enforce least-privilege rules
Hunt for queries with wildcards or high limits on sensitive collections

unique_mitre_techniques: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1559.002 - Inter-Process Communication: Dynamic Data Exchange
T1547.001 - Boot or Logon Autostart: Registry Run Keys
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files
T1048.001 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2
T1003.001 - OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory
